Description: Shoulder sherd of Corinthian black-figured pottery column-krater with turn to neck; interior: glazed black; exterior: black band at junction of neck and shoulder; below, black-figure decoration consisting of three padded dancers (from left, bearded face, garment in added red and left hand holding drinking horn, to right; at centre, upper body of second padded dancer, to left; at right, back of head and part of shoulder of third dancer, to right); incised spoked rosette and splinter rosette as filling ornament.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
For parallels, see British Museum 1924,1201.1304. Alexandridou and Venit both give this krater an Attic origin.
Bibliographic references: Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 122, pl. XXXVII, no. 346.4)
CVA Boston II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum USA, Fasc. 19, Museum of Fine Arts, Boston (p. 2, pl. 108, no. 2)
Alexandridou 2011 / The Early Black-Figured Pottery of Attika in Context (c. 630-570BCE) (p. 124) (Naukratis 113)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 230, no. 161)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.195) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5956 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
